Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Data-Driven Methodologies to Addressing the Driver Turnover and Shortage Problems in Truckload Transportation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the Truckload transportation industry, high driver turnover is a chronic problem, representing an annual cost of up to $2.8 billion. A primary reason is extended on-road times for drivers, largely a consequence of the point-to-point dispatching most often used in industry. Another related problem that is becoming increasingly important is the driver shortage, estimated to reach 239K in a decade, due to the retirement of the baby-boomer generation, an improving economy, and newly implemented hours-of-service regulations. The research will comprehensively investigate the driver turnover and shortage problems and address them through a systems-oriented design focus that also includes new proactive operational paradigms. In contrast to existing operational practices to fire-fight individual issues as they arise, a systems approach framework will take into account the perspectives of all stakeholders (drivers, companies, and customers) and involve modeling and analysis of both current and new systems and their operations via descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive analytics. The outcome of this research is expected to make substantial impact in addressing the turnover and shortage problems by providing a systems-oriented framework that incorporates both operational and turnover related costs while improving driver satisfaction with a data-driven collaborative dispatching tool. The research has the potential to significantly reduce an unproductive cost on the order of billions in the industry, and to benefit society by: 1) supporting the driver workforce (and families) with improved health, prosperity, and welfare, 2) unlocking the potential for employment opportunities for new workforce, and 3) reducing costs with improved transportation operations.

The system design and operations can improve driver satisfaction by better accommodating individual preferences for location, schedule regularity, mileage, and other factors while also improving economic measures important to all stakeholders. System development will proceed following a systems-oriented approach that is structured around a framework of three integrated analytical components. These components will be the product of 1) descriptive (designing and collecting field data from groups of drivers and dispatchers to determine the factors affecting truckload operations and turnover as well as their quantified contributions), 2) predictive (applying these data to the design of a new data-driven turnover prediction model in the context of a new collaborative dispatching paradigm), and 3) prescriptive (designing optimum relay and point-to-point networks via an optimization-and-simulation framework that incorporates collaborative dispatching/data-driven turnover prediction and considers operational costs (e.g., empty repositioning) as well as turnover costs obtained by the data-driven turnover prediction model) analytical methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to the American Trucking Association, approximately 71% of U.S. domestic goods are moved via “truckload” transportation, which typically involves a truck driver pulling a semi-trailer or freight container that is loaded to its capacity with goods provided by a single supplier. The drivers may cover great distances when delivering the full truckload to its destination. The drivers in this industry regularly face work-related difficulties such as longer times (and further distances) away from home, irregular work schedules, and less-than-satisfactory wages.

These characteristics of the truckload industry contribute to an unusually high job turnover rate: close to or greater than 100% annually, which means the average driver changes jobs once per year. Driver turnover leads to a significant cost to companies, estimated at $2.8 billion annually. These costs then impact the U.S. economy, as they are passed on to consumers in higher costs for transported goods.

A goal of our research is to understand the company-related, job assignment-related, and personal life-related factors that contribute to a driver’s decision to seek alternative employment. An online survey was broadly distributed to current truck drivers around the country. A large number of responding drivers (N=308) answered questions about their lives, their current job, and their near-term professional plans (such as the likelihood of changing jobs in the near future).  The data collected from survey responses were used to develop a model that estimates the risk of driver turnover, given characteristics of the driver, company, and hypothetical route assignments. This model can be used to guide administrative and operational (e.g., route assignment) decisions in the trucking industry, and also is being used in collaborative research to evaluate new operational paradigms for the trucking industry by considering driver job satisfaction and the cost of turnover as factors affecting business economics.

Survey results showed that turnover risk is lower when drivers are primarily assigned pre-planned routes, allowing them to better plan around personal life events. Drivers are also less likely to quit when more, rather than less work is assigned to them, often because pay depends on the amount of work they complete. Employers that provide childcare assistance tend to face lower turnover risks overall, especially for married/partnered drivers. Higher satisfaction with pay is associated with lower turnover, as is having a positive professional relationship with the dispatcher (who assigns routes) and supervisors, and drivers who reported each of these conditions showed the lowest turnover risk overall. However, drivers who have both higher annual salaries and strong company loyalty were associated with higher quitting likelihood. This apparently counterintuitive interaction may reflect other life factors, such as when drivers are approaching retirement.

The model showed how driver turnover risk was affected by an interaction between the driver’s employment duration and the duration of time over which training costs are repaid. When assessed independently, longer times for each are associated with lower turnover probability, however when both the driver’s time with the company and the time to repay training costs are longer, turnover probability increases. This finding likely reflects the practice of drivers staying with a company until they have repaid training costs, quitting shortly thereafter. A nonlinear relationship was found between the number of non-driving jobs a driver has had in the past and turnover likelihood. The prediction curve is cubic in nature, showing drivers with zero previous non-driving jobs associated with low turnover probabilities, while those with one previous non-driving job showing substantially higher turnover likelihood. This likelihood decreases for drivers that previously had 2-3 non-driving jobs, and finally increases again as the number of previous non-driving jobs increases beyond 3. This pattern may reflect general categories of drivers. We speculate that those who have no alternative work experience may feel more restricted to stay at their current job, while those who have at least some non-driving experience may feel more open to job changes. Drivers who have worked several non-driving jobs may have fully tried out other work domains and then settled into a career in trucking. The drivers with the highest numbers of previous non-driving jobs and higher likelihood of turnover may reflect “churning” practices, in which some drivers frequently change jobs to follow increases in pay or other advantages offered by companies in order to compete for drivers.

This work considered a large number of potential company, job, and personal factors as predictors of truckload driver turnover, incorporating the most influential factors into a predictive mathematical model. Following the assumption that drivers’ preferences for these different factors and their relative influence vary over time, future work can identify categories of drivers based on salient characteristics, and refine the predictive models within each category. In addition to advancing research into the factors affecting driver turnover, this work provides insight into means to improve the working conditions and personal lives of professional drivers.
